question: Do open-access articles receive more citations than subscription-only articles published in the same journal and year during the first year after publication? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The results of this natural experiment are clear: in the 4 to 16 months following publication, OA articles gained a significant citation advantage over non-OA articles during the same period.
content.source_2: Across the 4â€“10-month window, subscription-based (non-OA) papers garnered roughly twice the citations of OA articles, with the gap widening to nearly threefold between 10 and 16 months.
content.source_3: It provides robust evidence that open-access articles (OA articles) are more immediately recognized and cited than non-OA articles.
content.source_4: Longitudinal tracking indicates that any initial citation timing advantage for OA dissipates, and over multi-year follow-up there is no sustained increase in total citations relative to non-OA articles.
